definitions: subjected to physical or emotional harm through cruel treatment
used in a wrong or inappropriate way that causes damage
examples: The abused children needed years of therapy to heal
She felt abused by his constant criticism and insults
The abused system finally broke down from overuse
His abused privileges were eventually taken away completely

definitions: characterized by cruel and violent treatment toward another person
using or containing harsh insulting language intended to hurt
examples: The abusive parent was reported to child services
She finally left her abusive partner after years
His abusive comments made everyone in the meeting uncomfortable
The referee warned the player about his abusive language

definitions: extremely bad or appalling in quality or performance
so deep or great as to be immeasurable like an abyss
examples: The team's abysmal performance led to the coach's firing
Test scores were abysmal despite months of preparation
The submarine descended into the abysmal depths of the ocean
An abysmal chasm opened between the two mountains

definitions: relating to or denoting the depths of the ocean below 3000 meters
examples: Abyssal creatures have adapted to complete darkness and pressure
The abyssal plain covers most of the ocean floor

definitions: moving faster or happening more quickly than usual
progressed through stages more rapidly than normal
examples: The car's accelerated pace alarmed nearby pedestrians
Climate change is happening at an accelerated rate
She took an accelerated course to finish her degree early
The accelerated program allowed gifted students to skip grades

definitions: given special emphasis or prominence in design or decoration
spoken with a distinctive pronunciation indicating regional or foreign origin
examples: The accented colors made the painting more dramatic
Her outfit was accented with gold jewelry and accessories
His accented English revealed his Italian heritage
The accented syllables in poetry create its rhythm

definitions: generally believed or recognized as valid or correct
officially received or taken as adequate, valid, or suitable
examples: The accepted theory has been taught for decades
These are the accepted standards in our industry
All accepted students will receive notification letters this week
Only accepted forms of payment include cash and credit

definitions: willing to allow or approve of something or someone
able to tolerate or accommodate differences without criticism
examples: She was very accepting of the sudden change in plans
The accepting attitude of the staff made everyone comfortable
The community is accepting of people from all backgrounds
He became more accepting of others' opinions with age

definitions: contributing to or aiding an activity as a supplementary element
helping someone commit a crime but not as principal offender
examples: The scarf served as an accessory item to complete her outfit
These accessory features enhance the main product functionality
He was charged as an accessory to the robbery
Being an accessory after the fact is still illegal

definitions: happening by chance or unexpectedly without deliberate intent or cause
examples: The accidental discovery led to a major scientific breakthrough
Their accidental meeting at the cafe changed both their lives

definitions: willing to fit in with someone's wishes or needs in helpful way
examples: The accommodating staff made our stay extremely pleasant
She's very accommodating when it comes to schedule changes

definitions: going along with someone or occurring together with something else
examples: The accompanied tour includes a professional guide throughout
Children must be accompanied by an adult at all times

definitions: provided or occurring at the same time as something else
examples: The accompanying music enhanced the emotional impact of the scene
Please read the accompanying instructions before assembly begins

definitions: highly trained or skilled in a particular activity
successfully achieved or brought to completion
examples: She's an accomplished pianist who has performed worldwide
The accomplished chef opened her third restaurant this year
Once we accomplished our goal, we celebrated together
The accomplished mission boosted everyone's morale significantly

definitions: required or expected to justify actions or decisions to someone
examples: Managers are accountable for their team's performance results
Public officials must be accountable to the citizens they serve

definitions: officially recognized as meeting essential requirements or standards
examples: She graduated from an accredited university with honors
Only accredited laboratories can perform these specialized tests

definitions: accumulated or received over a period of time gradually
examples: His accrued vacation days allowed for a month-long trip
The accrued interest on the loan was surprisingly high

definitions: gradually gathered or acquired over a period of time
examples: The accumulated dust showed the room hadn't been used
Her accumulated knowledge made her an expert in the field

definitions: under a curse or seeming to bring bad fortune
examples: The accursed treasure brought misfortune to all who touched it
They fled from the accursed place before nightfall

definitions: suggesting someone has done something wrong or is at fault
examples: Her accusing tone made everyone in the room feel defensive
He pointed an accusing finger at the suspected thief

definitions: familiar with something through habit or regular occurrence
examples: She was accustomed to waking up early for work
The desert animals are accustomed to extreme temperature changes

definitions: of the highest quality or skill level excellently done
examples: He's an ace detective who solves the toughest cases
The ace pilot performed incredible maneuvers during the airshow

definitions: sharp and forthright in speech or manner often bitingly critical
examples: Her acerbic wit often offended more sensitive colleagues
The critic's acerbic review destroyed the new restaurant

definitions: relating to or containing acetic acid found in vinegar
examples: The acetic smell from the pickle factory filled the air
Acetic acid gives vinegar its characteristic sour taste

definitions: able to be brought about or accomplished successfully within reason
examples: Setting achievable goals helps maintain motivation throughout the project
The plan seemed achievable with our current resources available

definitions: causing a continuous dull pain in body or emotions
examples: Her aching muscles needed rest after the marathon
He felt an aching loneliness after his friend moved away

definitions: having the properties of an acid with pH below seven
examples: The acidic soil was perfect for growing blueberry plants
Lemons have an acidic taste that makes people pucker

definitions: accepted or admitted as true, valid, or legitimate generally
examples: She's the acknowledged expert in marine biology research
The acknowledged leader stepped forward to address the crowd

definitions: relating to sound or the sense of hearing properties
not electronically amplified referring to musical instruments
examples: The acoustic properties of the concert hall were perfect
Acoustic tiles on the ceiling reduced the echo significantly
She played an acoustic guitar around the campfire
The band's acoustic set created an intimate atmosphere

definitions: relating to the science and properties of sound
examples: The acoustical engineer designed the recording studio layout
Acoustical measurements showed the room needed sound treatment

definitions: having personal knowledge of someone through meeting or experience
examples: They became acquainted at the company holiday party
I'm acquainted with her work but we've never met

definitions: obtained or gained through effort or over time not innate
examples: His acquired wealth came from years of smart investments
The acquired skills made her valuable to any employer

definitions: formally declared not guilty of a criminal charge by verdict
examples: The acquitted defendant thanked his lawyer with tears
She was acquitted of all charges after new evidence emerged

definitions: angry and bitter in speech or manner typically during arguments
examples: Their acrimonious divorce proceedings lasted over two years
The acrimonious debate divided the community into opposing camps

definitions: requiring or displaying physical agility and coordinated movement skills
examples: The acrobatic performance left the audience breathless with amazement
Her acrobatic saves as goalkeeper won the championship game

definitions: temporarily doing the duties of another person's position
examples: The acting principal managed the school during her absence
He served as acting director for six months

definitions: providing sufficient reason to take legal action or practical steps
examples: The lawyer said we had actionable evidence for the lawsuit
The report contained actionable recommendations for improvement

definitions: made active or operational from a dormant or inactive state
examples: The activated alarm system detected the intruder immediately
Once activated, the emergency protocol cannot be stopped

definitions: causing something to begin working or become active
examples: The activating enzyme triggers the chemical reaction process
Pressing this activating switch starts the entire system

definitions: relating to the statistical calculation of insurance risks and premiums
examples: The actuarial analysis determined the life insurance rates
She studied actuarial science to work in insurance

definitions: caused to act or motivated by a particular feeling or desire
examples: He was actuated by a desire to help others succeed
The mechanism is actuated by pressing the red button

definitions: present or experienced to a severe or intense degree
having or showing keen mental perception and analytical ability
examples: The patient experienced acute pain in her lower back
The acute shortage of supplies forced rationing measures
Her acute observations helped solve the mystery quickly
He has an acute sense of timing in comedy

definitions: performed slowly and gracefully in musical tempo
examples: The adagio movement brought tears to the audience
Ballet dancers performed the adagio section with elegant precision

definitions: refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind determinedly
examples: She was adamant about not selling the family home
Despite protests, he remained adamant in his decision

definitions: able to adjust to new conditions or circumstances flexibly
examples: Adaptable employees thrive in changing work environments
The adaptable design works in various room sizes

definitions: modified to suit different conditions or purposes from original
examples: The adapted screenplay differed significantly from the novel
Desert plants are adapted to survive with minimal water

definitions: characterized by or showing ability to adapt to circumstances
examples: Adaptive learning technology adjusts to each student's pace
The bird's adaptive behavior helped it survive climate change

definitions: physically and mentally dependent on a particular substance or activity
examples: He became addicted to painkillers after his surgery
She was addicted to checking social media every hour

definitions: causing or likely to cause someone to become addicted
examples: The game's addictive gameplay kept players engaged for hours
Many people find chocolate to be highly addictive

definitions: added to something to improve or preserve it supplementally
examples: The food contains no artificial additive ingredients or preservatives
Additive manufacturing allows creation of complex shapes easily
